questions.text:
Which of the following statements about skin structure and embryology are correct?
1. The epidermis can regenerate from the hair bulb and sebaceous glands
2. The stratum corneum is the outermost cellular layer
3. The epidermis is of ectodermal origin
4. The dermis and hypodermis are of endodermal origin
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The epidermis can regenerate from the hair bulb and sebaceous glands because stem cells are located in the interfollicular region, base of sebaceous glands, and bulge area of hair follicle. (Statement 1 is true)

  • The stratum corneum is the outermost layer but it is anucleated and non-cellular, hence the outermost cellular layer is stratum granulosum. (Statement 2 is false) 
  • The epidermis develops from ectoderm. (Statement 3 is true) 
  • The dermis and hypodermis are mesodermal in origin (neural crest contribution in face and frontal scalp). (Statement 4 is false)

Key Takeaways:

  • Epidermis → ectoderm, dermis/hypodermis → mesoderm (neural crest in face).
  • Stem cell niches: interfollicular region, sebaceous gland base, bulge area of hair follicle.
  • Stratum granulosum is the outermost cellular layer.

questions.text:
Local side effects of topical corticosteroids among the following:
1. Blue discolouration of skin
2. Atrophy
3. Acneiform eruption
4. Hypertrichosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Blue discolouration of skin is not a side effect of corticosteroids

Topical corticosteroids cause a variety of local adverse effects due to dermal atrophy and altered follicular activity. (Mneumonic - STEROID)

  • S - Skin thinning (atrophy, striae) (Option 2 is true)
  • T-; Telangiectasia
  • E - Ecchymosis (easy bruising)
  • R -; Rosacea-like dermatitis
  • O - Opportunistic infections (folliculitis, tinea incognito)
  • I - Induced acne (steroid acne), Increased hair growth (hypertrichosis) (Option 3 and 4 are true)
  • D -; Decreased pigmentation and Delayed wound healing

Key Takeaway: Bluish-Grey Discolouration of Skin (Ceruloderma) is caused by

  • Antiarrhythmic: Amiodarone
  • Antibiotics: Minocycline
  • Antimalarials: Hydroxychloroquine, Chloroquine
  • Silver compounds: Argyria
  • Antipsychotic: Chlorpromazine

questions.text:
A 40-year-old asymptomatic patient presents with a progressive skin lesion over the neck and chest. There is no systemic involvement noted. What investigations are to be done in this patient?

1. KOH
2. Skin biopsy
3. Chest X-ray
4. HIV test
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical description suggests lupus vulgaris, a chronic, progressive paucibacillary form of cutaneous tuberculosis occurring in a previously sensitised individual.

  • Lesions are slow-growing plaques with raised margins and central atrophy; on diascopy they show apple-jelly nodules.

Investigations to be taken include:

  • Skin biopsy (diagnostic - shows tuberculoid granulomas with epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and caseous necrosis).
  • Chest X-ray (important since 10-20% of patients have associated pulmonary TB; cutaneous involvement may also be secondary to a pulmonary focus).

Explanation of other investigations:

(Investigation 1): This is more suggestive of a non-infective dermatosis (like cutaneous TB, leprosy,) rather than a superficial fungal infection. So, KOH is not necessarily taken.

(Investigation 4): HIV testing is not routinely indicated here unless there are other risk factors or clinical suspicion of immunosuppression.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lupus vulgaris = most common form of cutaneous TB, chronic plaque with central atrophy and apple-jelly nodules on diascopy.
  • Biopsy is essential for histopathological confirmation (tuberculoid granulomas with Langhans giant cells).
  • Chest X-ray is mandatory to rule out pulmonary TB (present in 10-20%).

questions.text:
A patient had recurrent oral ulcers and painful superficial eruptions in the genital area. A biopsy of the vesicular lesions was done.

What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Painful grouped vesicular lesions in the genital area that rupture to form multiple tender ulcers are characteristic of genital herpes (HSV infection).
  • Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells due to cell-to-cell fusion (syncytia formation) and acantholysis of keratinocytes.

The drug of choice is oral Acyclovir (200 mg five times daily or 400 mg three times daily for 7-10 days).

  • Alternative antivirals include valaciclovir and famciclovir.

Genital Herpes:

This is caused by HSV-2 (most cases), HSV-1 increasing in young adults and transmitted through sexual contact (asymptomatic viral shedding).

Clinical features

  • Primary infection: Painful grouped vesicles/ulcers on genitalia, dysuria, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, fever/malaise.
  • Recurrent infection: Usually milder, shorter, often preceded by tingling/burning prodrome.
  • Severity: Prior HSV-1 infection attenuates severity of HSV-2 primary infection.

Complications

  • Radiculoneuropathy: Sacral paraesthesia, urinary retention, constipation, impotence.
  • Meningism: Headache, neck stiffness; HSV DNA detectable by CSF PCR.
  • Encephalitis: Rare but serious.
  • Chronic verrucous HSV (esp. in HIV): Ulcers may persist, thicken, mimic neoplasia.

Treatment

  • First-line: Oral acyclovir, valaciclovir, or famciclovir (reduce duration & severity). Analgesia for pain.
  • Severe/atypical (HIV, verrucous, resistant): High-dose oral/IV acyclovir or valaciclovir ± cidofovir or imiquimod.

Explanation of other options:

Corticosteroids (Option B): Used in autoimmune blistering disorders (pemphigus, pemphigoid), not viral infections.

Penicillin (Option C): Drug of choice for syphilis, not herpes.

Azithromycin (Option D): Used in bacterial STIs like chlamydia, not viral herpes.

questions.text: A patient with a history of transient genital ulcers 2 weeks back, now presents with lesions on the palms and soles. Which of the following investigations can be used to diagnose the disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history of a transient genital ulcer (primary chancre) followed by symmetrical coppery-brown maculopapular rash over palms and soles is typical of secondary syphilis.

  • At this stage, serological tests can be used to diagnose the disease.

Secondary Syphilis:

  • Cause: Dissemination of Treponema pallidum in blood/lymph ~6-12 weeks after primary chancre.
  • General features: Constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, headache, bone/joint pains worse at night, lymphadenopathy generalised and rubbery).

Skin/mucosal lesions:

  • Rash: Symmetrical, non-itchy, coppery-brown maculopapular eruption; classically involves palms and soles.
  • Variability: May be macular, papular, lichenoid, pustular, or nodular → hence the "great imitator".
  • Mucous patches: Superficial, painless, greyish-white lesions on oral/genital mucosa.
  • Condylomata lata: Broad-based, moist, flat papules in anogenital folds, highly infectious.
  • Alopecia: Patchy,"moth-eaten" non-scarring alopecia.

Other manifestations: Iritis, hepatitis, glomerulonephritis, periostitis, meningitis (less common but possible).

Investigations: Serology (always positive in immunocompetent)

  • Screening: Nontreponemal (VDRL, RPR) - titres fall after treatment.
  • Confirmatory: Treponemal (TPHA, FTA-ABS, TPI) - remain positive lifelong.

Explanation of other options:

KOH mount (Option A): Used to detect fungal elements; not useful in syphilis.

Gram stain (Option B): Not useful since Treponema pallidum is too thin to be seen on Gram stain.

Tzanck smear (Option C): Used in herpes and other blistering diseases, not in syphilis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Secondary syphilis: non-itchy, coppery rash with palm and sole involvement, often with systemic features.
  • VDRL/RPR = screening tests; TPHA/FTA-ABS = confirmatory tests.
  • Characteristic findings: condylomata lata and moth-eaten alopecia.
